Message.Title: Apple to add second tactical data center in NC
Message.Msg: [Bump for Intel...] 21,030 square feet of high security Apple-style Apple is planning to add a second tactical data center to its main data center facility in North Carolina. The “tactical” data center will consist of 11 rooms and 21,030 square feet of high security that will house server clusters. The new “tactical” facility will not be used to house any employees, but it will have one unisex bathroom. It will also have a “man trap” and an 8-foot high chain link fence to secure the facility. Apple, of course, has no comment on what the facility will be used for or what information might be housed within it. Apple is also continuing work on a massive renewable energy project that will see the entire facility able to run on 100 percent renewable energy by the end of this year. Once completed, the new solar array that Apple is planning will be the largest end-user-owned array in the United States. http://fudzilla.com/home/item/28010-apple-to-add-second-tactical-data-center-in-nc

Message.Title: "technology sector is in better shape than Wall Street envisioned"
Message.Msg: Big tech stocks rally after early earnings reports Early earnings reports ease investors' worst fears about technology industry That wasn't so bad, after all. That's the sentiment among investors as they digest last week's smorgasbord of quarterly results from technology companies that included Intel Corp., IBM Corp., Microsoft Corp. and Google Inc. Although reports from the industry bellwethers all featured some troubling signs, their performances indicate the technology sector is largely holding up, even as Europe's debt crisis undercuts sales and threatens to topple a still-shaky U.S. economy into another recession. "What you are hearing now is a huge sigh of relief," said ISI Group analyst Brian Marshall. As they exhaled, many investors latched on to Intel, IBM, Microsoft and Google. All four of their stocks ended last week higher than they began. That was good news for the Dow Jones industrial average, which also edged upward. The index includes computer chip maker Intel, corporate technology specialist IBM and software maker Microsoft in its basket of 30 stocks that are supposed to reflect the state of U.S. industry. As a whole, the technology sector is in better shape than Wall Street envisioned. That's especially heartening amid signs that Europe's debt woes could cascade into a financial crisis similar to the 2008 meltdown in the U.S. that deepened the Great Recession. The technology-driven Nasdaq composite index ended last week 7 percent higher than where it stood at the beginning of June. http://finance.yahoo.com/news/big-tech-stocks-rally-early-070304653.html

Topic.Title: Morris Chang Comments on Q2 2012: 28nm, 20nm, 16nm, FinFets, CAPEX, etc…

Message.Msg: "Tape outs don't mean that production is starting anytime soon. I suspect that TSMC's charge per wafer policy will keep any potential at bay as they don't want to help fund the development cycle for the benefit of their competitors." Actually it does. A tape-out costs millions of dollars, mask sets etc.... Companies like Broadcom, Qualcom, Oracle, Xilinx, Altera, Nvidia, AMD, etc only tape-out when they are confident the process is ready. TSMC 20nm tape-outs will begin in Q1 2013 and you will see first silicon 6-9 months following. 20nm production ramp will be first half of 2014. I spent last week in Taiwan talking about this amongst other things: http://www.semiwiki.com/forum/content/1483-tsmc-reports-second-highest-quarterly-profit.html

Topic.Title: Hey Alexander --- what is the dollar amount of the ...

Message.Msg: You put too much faith in my abilities. 8-) I sent a request to Intel IR requesting comment on the article and if it was accurate but have not heard back. I still will follow up. I was planning on posting their reply. IMO, the unfunded liability is much lower than Fitch states. I may dig through Fitch releases to see how they arrived at their numbers if the information is publicly available. It would be pretty hard to reproduce the Fitch numbers without knowing some pension plan information about employee 401k plans. Intel funds annual contributions to employees 401k plans. Intel also matches some extra employee added contributions. The Intel pension plan is a defined benefit plan that pays based on years of service and only in the event of the employee 401k not meeting the computed service-time pension payout. So, the Intel pension plan only pays if the employee does a very bad job of managing his investments in the plan. Since Intel controls the mutual funds and ETF that are available, they are pretty conservative and pretty much track the markets. I doubt that Fitch has access to the balances in the employee 401k's so they probably computed the plan short fall assuming that it was going to have to pay everyone.

Topic.Title: Hey Alexander --- what is the dollar amount of the ...

Message.Msg: Nothing back yet but some information. If you page through their presentation, Intel contributes 6% of an employees salary to a 401k plan. I think that employees that leave Intel abandon the Intel contributed pension funds which are distributed to active participants. I don't see how Fitch can calculate a 40% funding. The 6% contributions are made in cash and benefits from those accounts more than cover the pension commitment. LAST PARAGRAPH: "The pension plan pays a benefit only to the extent that it is not fully offset by the retirement contribution plan account value." PARAGRAPH #3: "For 2011, Intel's discretionary contribution (including allocable forfeitures) to the retirement contribution plan for eligible U.S. employees, including executive officers, and to the similar account for new employees in the 401(k) savings plan, equaled 6% of eligible salary (which included annual and semiannual incentive cash payments as applicable)." http://www.intc.com/intelProxy2012/statement/compensation/other/arrangements/

Message.Title: HF Trading Stealing Wealth frpm INTC
Message.Msg: Isn't it about time to stop the market manipulation by high frequency computer trading which governs 70% of INTC's shares traded? Pure and simple it is nothing but market manipulation that transfers wealth from INTC's shareholders to the Wall Street robbers. One week these programs run INTC shares up and they sell call options, the next week it is down. In sum, despite earnings doubling over the past five years, INTC's share price is basically unchanged. Not just INTC's shares are being manipulated, but many other mature tech stocks: AMAT, NVLS, KLAC, STX, WDC, etc. Isn't it about time to put an end to this scam? INTC must join others and speak up!

Our practice is to fund the various pension plans and the U.S. postretirement medical benefits plan in amounts sufficient to meet the minimum requirements of U.S. federal laws and regulations or applicable local laws and regulations. Topic.Title: Hey Alexander --- what is the dollar amount of the ...

Message.Msg: Thanks for the update. My guess is that the pension plan is completely separate from 401(k) accounts (they usually are) --- especially since there was a mention in one of your quotes to a "define benefit plan" (which are PRECISELY the type that run into problems in the later years if the contributions and investment earnings do not keep pace with the assumptions under which the plan is being administered (which is also the problem with Social Security as it is defined benefit also)). Many (if not most) companies switched from defined benefit to defined contribution plans for this reason. Anyway, I am not a pension expert by any means, though I was married to one for many years, and my guess is that all public corporations are required to divulge the status of their pension fund plans since it represents a future obligation of the corporation, and I would guess Fitch used that publicly available data. SOOOOOOOO, I imagine the info is available somewhere from Intel. I'm still thinking it will turn out that while the % unfunded (which is what the article cited), the actual dollar amount may be negligible, and I was hoping that one of you diehard Intel investors could readily debunk or verify the article. emo 77777777777777

Topic.Title: ARM grabs TSMC's 3D FinFETs for future 64-bit PC brains

Message.Msg: Wow. Looks like no 64-bit ARM at the 20nm process node. You can forget about any ARM based server without 64-bit. The implication here is huge: Intel has the entire server market for years to come with little/no competition.

Message.Title: "we are unlikely to see 20nm phones and tablets anytime soon..."
Message.Msg: [Slow production and only one flavor. The examples of the ARM fabrication crisis never stop...] TSMC plans low volume 20nm production in 2013 TSMC plans to start volume 20nm production in 2014, but low-volume production is slated to start next year. TSMC CEO Morris Chang claims “some” production of 20nm parts will start next year, but on a very small scale. “Very low, what we would call a risk type of production basically,” he said. Chang added that 2014 will be a “ramp year” for 20nm SoCs, which means we are unlikely to see 20nm phones and tablets anytime soon. This also means that roughly two generations of upcoming GPUs will probably stick to the current 28nm process. Interestingly, TSMC will offer only one version of its 20nm process to partners. The new tech will have to fit all applications, from high-performance GPUs to power efficient smartphone chips.

Message.Title: Just A Thought
Message.Msg: Although the major indexes recovered more than half of their early losses by the close, breadth didn't improve much as the smaller stocks stayed weak throughout the day. The Russell 2000 broke its up trendline started in June today. The other major indexes aren't very far from breaking their up trendlines. Negative divergences have shown up in RSI as well as new 52-week lows, as the new 52-week lows on the NYSE rose to the highest level since late June. Stocks are not oversold. Expect more pullbacks over the near term. Notable earnings due out on Tuesday include: T, UPS, NSC, MO, WHR, PNRA, NFLX, BIIB, BRCM, JNPR and AAPL.

Topic.Title: ARM grabs TSMC's 3D FinFETs for future 64-bit PC brains

Message.Msg: Article is so poorly written that even the simple math doesn't work! "FinFETs to come out during the 14nm phase, which will go into risk production in 2014" ??? "That's about a year behind Intel." No that's about 2 years but we all know that production of 20Nm is more likely in 2014 and TSMC FinFets will be 2015 at the earliest. So really it's 3 years and by that time Intel will have 10Nm and market share. Remember the capacity that Intel has built in, all will be online in a year or two.

Topic.Title: Morris Chang Comments on Q2 2012: 28nm, 20nm, 16nm, FinFets, CAPEX, etc…

Message.Msg: 'A dual core 1.5 Ghz Krait chip has a 0.75W TDP under maximum load, while Atom has 2.6w TDP in “idle mode” alone (when your phone does nothing), and 3.6W when playing a 720p video. So that’s around 4, maybe 5 times less efficient than the best ARM chip right now.' Completely made up BS numbers on both sides i.e QCOM actually state 0.75W per core not per chip and those Medfield numbers are plucked from his posterior. In the real world Medfield is very competitive e.g. 1.6 GHz Medfield beats 1.5 GHz Krait in Web Browsing battery life with a 12% smaller battery ! http://www.anandtech.com/show/5868/htc-one-s-review-international-and-tmobile/2 'The biggest benefit of multi-core chips, besides the performance boost for multi-threaded applications like the browser and some games, is multi-tasking. Multi-tasking might not be extremely important in a smartphone, and is indeed more important on a tablet, but I’d still take at least a dual-core phone over a single core one, if given the choice.' The dumbass doesn't realize that Medfield has two threads on its single core which sums up his general ignorance. Medfield still the SunSpider King ... http://www.anandtech.com/show/5868/htc-one-s-review-international-and-tmobile/3

Topic.Title: "we are unlikely to see 20nm phones and tablets anytime soon..."

Message.Msg: Do you think Motorola will finally launch some Intel based smartphones by October or November, to be ready for Holiday season. I'm still anxious to get one. My iPhone which I only use once in a while in Wifi locations, has very little batterly life since its battery cannot be replaced. It would be great to try something that is really different such as a more performance based Intel smartphone. Can't wait!

Topic.Title: "we are unlikely to see 20nm phones and tablets anytime soon..."

Message.Msg: I hope so and I don't think they are just sitting around in the meantime. I'm guessing a lot of energy is going into making the product competitive...

Topic.Title: "we are unlikely to see 20nm phones and tablets anytime soon..."

Message.Msg: By the way, I was just looking at my netbook powered by Intel. It hardly gets used unless I travel. But it does come in handy during my trip. I mostly am comfortable using a desktop with at least a 24" screen. So when I get my smartphone, I see no reason to own a tablet. As for my netbook, I would be very interested in updating it with an ultrabook. An ultrabook with a comfortable conversion to a tablet mode would be interesting but not a must. I usually go with what makes common sense. So over the long run, I think Intel has it right as to what model will have sustainable growth over the next 5 years or more. As for my thoughts on tablets, or the iPad, I consider it a total waste of money. The only way I will buy one is if somebody does what HP did with the touchpad. I would be will to pay around $100 for some entertainment use along with Wifi internet use. That's it!

Message.Title: At Last It Makes Sense
Message.Msg: I finally figured it out. Wall Street has Alzheimer's. That's why Greece got priced in 23 times. Wall street just got up each day and said, "OMG, look what is happening in Greece!!! We've never seen this before. We had better price it in." And why last quarter's miss got priced in 5 times. And why Lucy says the same exact thing again and again and again. And doesn't understand why we say it wasn't funny the first time. Lucy thinks every time is the first time. Warning to board: Watch out. Wall Street is going to want to price Greece in for the first time tomorrow...
